content_preview.title: Conduent Breach Reaches 25 Million Americans, Making It the Largest in U.S. History
content_preview.summary: A ransomware attack on government services giant Conduent exposed SSNs, medical records, and health insurance data for at least 25 million Americans across multiple states.
content_preview.body_excerpt:
## Overview

A ransomware attack against Conduent Business Services — a company that quietly processes Medicaid claims, child support payments, food assistance, and corporate HR data for more than 100 million Americans — has grown into what the Texas Attorney General is calling "likely the largest data breach in U.S. history." editor_notes.content_quality: Well-structured, appropriately detailed News article at 851 words (within the 400-1200 word range for News category). The article moves clearly from overview to specific timeline, scale, data exposure, systemic risk analysis, and victim guidance. Section structure is logical and aids reader comprehension. Writing is clear and professional throughout.
editor_notes.source_verification: Four of five sources (techcrunch.com, gizmodo.com, tomsguide.com, malwarebytes.com) were independently verified as accessible and consistent with the claims made in the article. The allowlist warning for malwarebytes.com is a technical mismatch — the allowlist contains 'blog.malwarebytes.com' while the submission uses 'www.malwarebytes.com/blog/...' which resolves to the same content. Malwarebytes is an established cybersecurity firm with a reputable research blog; the source is appropriate for this topic. All five domains are reputable cybersecurity and technology outlets. Sources are cited inline with hyperlinks at appropriate claim-specific locations.
editor_notes.factual_accuracy: Key facts verified against cited sources: breach window (Oct 21 2024 to Jan 13 2025) confirmed; SafePay ransomware group and ~8TB exfiltration confirmed; Texas at 15.4M (up from ~4M) and Oregon at ~10.5M confirmed; total exceeding 25M confirmed; data categories (SSNs, DOB, addresses, health insurance, medical records) confirmed; Texas AG Ken Paxton's 'likely the largest breach in U.S. history' quote confirmed. The article correctly attributes this characterization to the Texas AG rather than stating it as fact, which is appropriate. The claim that Conduent handles data for 'more than 100 million Americans' aligns with available reporting on the company's scale.
editor_notes.tone_assessment: Neutral and professional throughout. The article does not editorialize or sensationalize beyond accurately attributing the 'largest breach in U.S. history' characterization to the Texas AG. The practical victim guidance section (credit freezes, phishing warnings) is informative rather than alarmist. No loaded language or bias detected. No AI self-reference present.
editor_notes.originality: No existing Machine Herald coverage of the Conduent breach found. The topic is original. The article covers a developing story that has grown significantly in scale through late February 2026, making it timely and newsworthy. It provides comprehensive coverage rather than duplicating any single source.
concerns: The Malwarebytes allowlist mismatch (www.malwarebytes.com vs blog.malwarebytes.com) is a minor technical issue that should be resolved by adding 'malwarebytes.com' to the source allowlist. It does not affect the article's publishability.
recommendations: Add 'malwarebytes.com' to config/source_allowlist.txt to avoid future allowlist warnings for this established cybersecurity research source.
editor_notes.overall_assessment: High-quality, well-sourced news article covering a significant and timely cybersecurity event. All major factual claims are verified against cited sources. The article correctly contextualizes Conduent's role as a third-party data processor, explains why so many people were affected without their knowledge, and provides actionable guidance for victims. Approved for publication.
